page.enlisting:
• Synthetic GOES-R data created using the RAMS numerical model and radiative transfer code • Emphasis on applications to mesoscale weather (severe storms, tropical cyclones, snow bands) • Advanced Ensemble Kalman Filter Data Assimilation System also under development • Example below shows impact of HES horizontal resolution on simulated CAPE DPI • Other examples on the poster
• Synthetic GOES-R data created using the RAMS numerical model and radiative transfer code
• Emphasis on applications to mesoscale weather (severe storms, tropical cyclones, snow bands)
• Advanced Ensemble Kalman Filter Data Assimilation System also under development
• Example below shows impact of HES horizontal resolution on simulated CAPE DPI
• Other examples on the poster

picture.caption: Figure 1: Synthesized GOES 10.7 μm brightness temperatures within Grid 3 of the simulated convective event. The blue box demarks the location of Grid 4.
picture.name: Image58

picture.caption: Figure 2: Synthetic DPI (CAPE) within Grid 4 of the simulated convective event using 50, 30, 10, and 4 km footprint.

page.title:
Atmospheric Motion Vectors from the Current GOES- I/M Series with an Eye on Opportunities with the Future GOES-R/U Series
Atmospheric Motion Vectors from the Current GOES-
I/M Series with an Eye on Opportunities with the Future
GOES-R/U Series
page.normal_text:
Jaime Daniels1, Chris Velden2, Wayne Bresky3, and Antonio Irving4 NOAA/NESDIS Office of Research and Applications1, Camp Springs, Maryland Cooperative Institute for Meteorological Satellite Studies (CIMSS)2, Univ. of Wisconsin-Madison Raytheon Information Technology and Scientific Services3, Lanham, Maryland NOAA/NESDIS Office of Satellite Data Processing and Distribution4, Camp Springs, Maryland

D i s t r i b u t i o n 4 ,

S p r i n g s ,
M a r y l a n d

Atmospheric motion vectors (AMVs), derived from the current GOES-I/M series of satellites, continue to provide valuable wind information to the Numerical Weather Prediction (NWP) and weather forecasting communities. The future instruments being planned for the GOES-R/U series of satellites offer exciting new capabilities that should directly benefit and improve the derivation and quality of the AMVs. These capabilities include: continuous scanning with no loss of imagery due to eclipse or conflicting scanning schedules, higher resolution (spectral, spatial and temporal) imagery, and improved navigation.
Atmospheric motion vectors (AMVs), derived from the current GOES-I/M series of satellites,
continue to provide valuable wind information to the Numerical Weather Prediction (NWP) and
weather forecasting communities. The future instruments being planned for the GOES-R/U
series of satellites offer exciting new capabilities that should directly benefit and improve the
derivation and quality of the AMVs. These capabilities include: continuous scanning with no loss
of imagery due to eclipse or conflicting scanning schedules, higher resolution (spectral, spatial
and temporal) imagery, and improved navigation.

Today, areas of active AMV research include the generation, validation, and impact assessment of rapid scan winds derived from high temporal frequency imagery, error characterization and improvement of tracer height assignment, utilization of additional channels (ie, 3.9um) for derivation of AMVs, and improved utilization of AMVs in NWP systems. This research will lay the scientific foundation so that the anticipated improvements in AMVs in the GOES-R era can be realized. This poster will highlight many of these active AMV research topics.
Today, areas of active AMV research include the generation, validation, and impact assessment
of rapid scan winds derived from high temporal frequency imagery, error characterization and
improvement of tracer height assignment, utilization of additional channels (ie, 3.9um) for
derivation of AMVs, and improved utilization of AMVs in NWP systems. This research will lay the
scientific foundation so that the anticipated improvements in AMVs in the GOES-R era can be
realized. This poster will highlight many of these active AMV research topics.
